A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.

A polynomial with coefficients in a field or ring is defined as a formal sum $f=\sum_{j=0}^{n} a_{j} X^{j}$, where $a_{j}$ are the coefficients. This definition emphasizes that a polynomial is identified with the sequence of its coefficients.
Does the concept of a/an Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Polynomial to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Polynomial specifies that it is a formal sum where the coefficients are elements from a field or a ring. This implies that the concept of a ring (or field, which is a special type of ring) is fundamental to defining what these coefficients are and how they behave. Without understanding what a ring is, one cannot fully grasp the structure and properties of the coefficients in a polynomial. Therefore, the concept of a ring is necessary to provide a complete and meaningful definition of a polynomial, as it establishes the algebraic framework within which polynomials operate.
